On Mon, 12 Jul 2004, Martijn Dashorst wrote:

> > Right. But the problem is finding that one important failure in the list
> > of 250 failures that you got from your test run.
>
> If the database connection fails that often, perhaps it is necessary to
> solve that particular problem.

It doesn't fail that often, which makes it even worse, because you've
forgotten what caused the error last time.

But let's put this back in perspective. Here's the situation:

    1. I have a test that I know, if it fails, many other tests will
    produce invalid results.

    2. In most cases, if I fix only this test, all the other tests will
    then pass, too.

    3. It may well be possible, us being programmers and all, to explain
    this to the computer, so that we as humans do not have to do the
    tedious work of searching through a lot of errors for the one
    "important" one.

So which of these two is the correct conclusion?

    A. We should try to find a simple way of explaining this to the
    computer, so that we as humans save time and effort.

    B. We should forget about improving the current system, and continue
    to do a tedious search through the manual list, justifying this by
    coming up with various excuses as to how other things should be
    fixed.

I suppose this really divides us up into three sorts of people. Those
who can find a solution to A, those who can't and are thus forced to
continue with B, and those who do not want to find a solution to A. I
can tell you right now, I'm B at the moment, but I have hope at some
point of getting to to A. I invite the rest of you to consider which
of these types of person you are.

cjs
